senses.sense_definition: To travel from one region to another at specific times of the year, usually to find food, breeding grounds, or warmer weather (typically referring to animals or birds).

examples.text: Many species of birds <w>migrate</w> south to escape the freezing winter temperatures.
Whales <w>migrate</w> thousands of miles every year to reach their breeding grounds.

senses.sense_definition: To move from one country, region, or place to another in order to live or work there permanently or for a long time.

examples.text: My grandparents decided to <w>migrate</w> to the United States in search of better opportunities.
People often <w>migrate</w> from rural areas to large cities to find employment.

senses.sense_definition: To transfer data, software, or systems from one computer, network, or platform to another.

examples.text: The IT department plans to <w>migrate</w> all user data to the new server over the weekend.
It can be difficult to <w>migrate</w> legacy software to a modern operating system.

senses.sense_definition: To move slowly or gradually from one place to another, often in a group.

examples.text: As the party continued, guests began to <w>migrate</w> towards the kitchen where the food was.
The crowd started to <w>migrate</w> to the front of the stage as the band prepared to play.

senses.sense_definition: To shift gradually from a correct or intended position to an unintended one (often used in medical or technical contexts).

examples.text: Without proper fixation, the implant may <w>migrate</w> and cause pain to the patient.
Over time, the fluids can <w>migrate</w> into areas where they cause mechanical damage.
